content.description:
“The philosophy of the eighteenth century takes up . . . the methodological pattern of Newton’s physics, though it immediately begins to generalize from it. It is not content to look upon analysis as the great intellectual tool of mathematical and physical knowledge; eighteenth-century thought sees analysis rather as the necessary and indispensable instrument of all thinking in general. This view triumphs in the middle of the [eighteenth] century. However much individual thinkers and schools differed in their results, they agreed in this methodological premise.”
Ernst Cassirer, German historian, The Philosophy of the Enlightenment, 1932
content.question: The influence of Newton’s methodology described in the passage is best understood in the context of which of the following?

choices.label: The continued popularity of spiritual and supernatural explanations for physical phenomena
The spreading influence of thought associated with the Scientific Revolution
The growth of knowledge resulting from the explorations of European overseas traders and missionaries
The rising economic influence of the merchant and professional classes

content.answer: The spreading influence of thought associated with the Scientific Revolution

topic.text: 4.1: Contextualizing the Scientific Revolution and Enlightenment

skill.text: Skill 4.A: Identify and describe a historical context for a specific historical development or process.
